description: From Latin candidātus (“a person who is standing for public office”), from candidus (“dazzling white, shining, clear”) + -ātus (an adjectival suffix), in reference to Roman candidates wearing bleached white togas as a symbol of purity at a public forum. Equivalent to candid +‎ -ate.

entries.meaning: A person who is running in an election.
examples: Smith announced he was the party's candidate for the next election.

entries.meaning: A person who is applying for a job.
examples: All candidates who miss the deadline or make a spelling mistake in their applications are automatically rejected.
Candidates must remain silent for the entirety of the exam.

entries.meaning: Something or somebody that may be suitable.
examples: After being presented with various suitors, she decided none of the candidates were the kind of man she was looking for.

entries.meaning: (genetics) A gene which may play a role in a given disease.

verbs.description: candidate (third-person singular simple present candidates, present participle candidating, simple past and past participle candidated)

entries.meaning: (uncommon) To stand as a candidate for an office, especially a religious one.
examples: The matter of candidating for a pulpit is not a matter of difference between congregations and Rabbis, but between Rabbis themselves.

entries.meaning: (nonstandard, chiefly in jargon and non-native speakers' English) To make or name (something) a candidate (for use, for study as a next project, for investigation as a possible cause of something, etc).
examples: Performance comparison of solar energy conversion candidated for SPS. (From  NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center, Houston 1977.)
